div1.p:
Irwin C. Fox
Sergt C.E. 152nd
Ind. Vol
1st Brig-e 3rd Div-n 1st

Summit Point Va July 11th 1865
on Picket

div3.head: Camp Carrington Mar 15 th
div3.p: Enlisted at Rendalville Md in 152 Regt Ind. on Feb 13th for one year occuped time until the night of the 16 writing for Capt Smith left for Indianapolis at 12 P M

div3.head: 16th
div3.p:
inst. arived
via Salem Crossing arrived there at daylight

div3.head: 17th
div3.p:
inst tavern being crowded went to a private house and got a good breakfast and got acquainted with a nice war widow & left there at eleven for Camp - got there at ten P.M. found it in a very mudy condition were delayed
about two hours reporting and getting quarters we were scattered all over four of us got together in a Barrack No 1 already full we lay on the mudy floor some of the new chaps thought it rough but it was endureable. Next morn. got assigned to Barracks N. 7 with the most of the Company - got the men together but had not enough to muster. so we had to recruit more men - which proved a slow job Moved to WOUS on Mar 1 organized company Mar 4 with 91.
men present Walds Chrrid - Cap Livermorhouse 1st & M Boyd 2nd Middleburg being artillery to [-] the chore fell upon myself - Walds Chrrid - being appointed Major then was changing of places J. F. Carrington coming in first Lieut Livermorhouse Capt C M Boyd retaining Second Lieut. Our duty is very light drilling comenced yesterday Mar 14 - rains most of the time now heare the [--]
Sing last night done it up in splendid style The Theatre is [-] by our Boys [-] The play of Fadille [--] was superb Miss Thompson playing the part of Famshar Fareing good & comfortable Baracks etc many sick etc principally Fiver colds measles Mumps etc -

1st drew arms. Endfield Rifles I prefered Springfield - but they were all issued before we were full received orders to leave on the 18th for Harpers Ferry Va Saturday morning Nine [-] we [-]
our company [-] for the journey to Va Left Camp Carrington at one P.M. for [-] stoped in front of Genl. Carringtons Head quarters and received a short speech from him in which he went over about the same things that we had heard him give the boys that went before us the most of us left camp without any regrets for soldiers are always ready for chances although it may be for worse we marched to the
Bates house [-] formed the Regt in solid column listened to a short address from Chaplain [-] Bro Morton being absent the afternoon was nearly spect when we got on the cars and started on our journey [-] we run all night & Sunday morn arrived at Columbus Ohio stoping here for a short time we soon started again got to Zanesville Ohio at dark had one little scare near Zanesville we took on the cars.
was full of soldiers and one of the cars run of the track the boys finding it out commenced jumping off when the cars were in full motion there being a high bluff on one side and the river on the other the train soon stopped and strange to say no one was hurt we soon got the car on the track again we had quite a time in Zanesville forageing about town etc we started at eight O clock Monday morning in passing through the town we had to cross
The Muskingum River on a bridge that is 75 or 80 feet above the stream which is very rapid while crossing a soldier of Co H fell from the top of the cars through the Bridge into the river. He rose twice and swam some distance both times but the current was to swift for him and he went down nothing more of importance hapened until we reached Bellair on the Ohio River here we crossed on the Ferry boat at the same place I crossed in /61 after crossing we were packed into Freight cars again we lay still on the track all night
Started at five [-]

div3.head: Mar 21st
div3.p:
nothing of importance hapened the road runs through a very rough country the Regt done some pretty hard stealing all the way from Indianopolis today they stole six Barrells of Apples Co. E. getting the most of them raining most of the time a little after dark came to the town of Fetterman my home for a short time in Feb of /62 and also the town of Grafton which looked quite natural to me at least it being the scene of home of the doings of the old ninth Ind
We run all night about midnight we got to Cranbery Summit in the mountains we found it very cold the mountains covered with ice and snow but we soon got into a milder region about ten A.M Wednesday we got to Cumberland Md here we stoped a while and had a good time generally got to harpers Ferry some time in the night at least at daylight Thursday morning we found ourselves at that hole in the mountains we lay there until eight oClock looked around
a little Saw the place of John Browns exploits it stands at the Junction of the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers the Potomac is crossed by a Iron Bridge it is a wild looking place Maryland Hights across the Potomak from the Ferry are very high the summit is crowned with a Battery of guns at eight o clock the train started up the valley for Charlestown our place of destination arived there in good time the day so far was warm and pleasant we got off
the cars and marched out about a mile to our camp but we changed our situation several times so we finaly settled down about 1/2 mile from town in the mean time it had commenced raining and blowing furiously but after some persevering efforts we got our tents pitched a spent our first nights in tents

div3.head: Mar 24th
div3.p:
weather continues cold and disagreeable caught cold and feel poor done duty principaly policing quarters etc. 25 storms hard again snow nearly an inch
deep in morning but came of pleasant
"Keep pretty close in quarters cominced drilling today" I went out in morning but did not feel well but staid out until noon and then went to bed for the remainder of the day - taken with Chills -
got my chills broke today but feel badly considerable pain in my head excused from duty
worse to day face swelled also back part of my head Docter calls it Neuralgia but can do nothing for me at present at night I put on Bread poultice

am no better
head pained me badly but I am as well cared for as possible here
Continue about the same get no medicine but a few powders which I will not take by any means Continue about the same until April 1 when I began to improve but am still quite weak

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p:
Grand review today I do not feel able to go but it is reported Genl. Hancock is to review us so I thought I would try it I started and staid out two hours and then being no signs of its closing I started for camp we had to stand with our Knapsack on
The exertion was to much for me and was worse again I did no duty until April 4 when we got marching orders I managed to get my Knapsack with the Officers Baggage we were detailed for wagon Guards and did not leave Charlestown until nearly five oclock P.M. while the rest of the Brigade left in the morning but after we did start we came pretty fast we marched until two Oclock next morning coming 15 miles we were pretty sore many fell behind it was a pretty hard march for the first
the men not being used to marching or carrying Knapsacks I should have fell out if we had gone a mile further but managed to reach the Regt although I was some distance behind when they halted I got to the Company and got in with a comrad I having no Blankets of my own the night was pretty cold but I was tired and I rested very well considering circumstances.

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
arose at half past Five not exactly at half that time either for I was at least five minutes getting
Straitened up drank a cup of coffee and felt better about 7 - O clock we resumed our march up the valley The most of the Country is striped of fences and many of the houses deserted but once in a while we found a farm with fences up a sign that he played a double game for if he had been a Union man the Rebs would have stripped him in their numerous excursions through the valley and if he had been a Reb in the eyes of our men
we would certainly have made camp fires of his rails and confiscated his stock etc At noon we halted for an hour for dinner rest etc we stoped in sight of Winchester but did not go through it we passed to the left and took partly a backward course for five miles or more and stoped at five oclock near Stephens Station on the R.R. we got up our tents in good time and had a good supper went to bed and enjoyed a good nights sleep

div3.head: 7th
div3.p:
lay in camp and rested most of the day feeling pretty sore this
being our first march we are en camped one half mile west of Stevns Stat. on high ground very good place for camp this country is much better for camping than the western country especially in the vicinity of the Streams the soil is a stiff clay a little rain makes it very disagreeable walking -

div3.head: 8th
div3.p:
commenced drill again weather cold at night but pleasant good news from Grants Army continues to pour in there is general rejoicing throughout the camps & we watch eargly for
the Newsboys to come with the daily papers Lees surrender would have suited some of us would
better if they had not have given them so good terms but perhaps it is for the best they may be more willing to come back if we are liberal with them but as for the leaders they must be punished for the crime of Treason or all of our troubles will not cease with this Rebellion if they are allowed to escape with light punished it will encourage treason all over the world it is almost like offering a bounty for treason
because it will show the world that Treason to be honorable must only be successful Spent most of our time in drilling that is six hours a day roumors about camp say we are soon to go up the vally to Staunton but I don't think we shall as there must be as many men there as they need Mosby Emboden and some minor Gurrella Chiefs are still at Carye in the valley but I think we will soon give them a chase

div3.head: 10th
div3.p:
still stay in camp good news
continues to arrive the boys begin to think about going home sometime this summer some are shure we will not stay two months but my opinion is we will stay most of the summer at least continue Drilling and doing Guard Duty until the 15th Saturday morning early when we received orders to prepare for a raid after Mosby in light marching order we were to start at twelve [-]. about ten we got news of President Lincolns assassination and also of the Messrs [-]
and the order for the raid was countermanded we were to take three days rations in our haver sacks and six days in our wagons we were expecting to capture plenty of forage and possibly Mosby himself we were expecting to have a good to have been able to capture Mosbys gang would have been doing pretty well for a new Regt. and there being plenty of old soldiers in our Regt. and they wold like to have at least one brush
with the boys before going home but now every other thought has given place to profound sorrow and deep indignation at the death of our President who now more than ever is honored and respected by all partys and sections but his work nto done Standing at the head of a nation that has no superiors he is suddenly stricken down by the cowardly hand of an assassin whose name will be handed
down to posterity along with that of Judas
[ word lined through]
Iscariot but he will not escape the ha nd of Justice he will sooner or latter meet the punishment which his crimes deserve The south may well sorrow along with us for this act she has lost a friend She will not find in his success or the crime probably was that of an individual or individuals but it is but a shoot form Proof of that stupenduous rebellion that has caused the life blood of thousands of our
Soldiers to be pour ed out but but this was a cool fiendish murder while the soldier accepts his chances of life or death when he enlists but the man who killed the President struck down the only ha nd that could or would show them any mercy and they will soon see it Johnson has seen and suffered to much hims elf to give them any thing but Justice in its strictest sence he knows what a hellish spirit under -lies this whole system of slavery which is the foundation of
Rebellion - Some of the men receive the news with oaths of indgnation others in silence being to awe stricken for speech for my part I feel like shooting somebody well to be honest I am fighting mad I think we could do Mosby Justice now but we hear rumors of his being about to surrender

div3.head: 15th
div3.p:
Pleasant weather - done some washing as we for one{1} had no extra duty for Sunday. rumor says that the President is
Still alive but it is hardly probale -

div3.head: 17th
div3.p:
the news of The Presidents death is confirmed but after the news we had received befor we were expec ting it - our orders are to strengthen the Picket lines and arrest everyone that come to the lines - We manage to live prety well by buying Thre or four barrels of Bread a day and an occational mess of Krout & Potatoes for our tent containing five our government rations do not hold
out or rather we do not receive our allowence some of them we do get are spoiled and useless it makes much trouble for Sergt etc as many of the boys blame them instead of the Comissary but we hope to soon get things in better shape Our Qurartermaster & commissary sergeant are standing a court - Marshall yesterday and today and probably that Department will run more smooth after such an ordeal.

div3.head: 18th.
div3.p:
Stormy & cold tommrrow all labor is to be suspended to in honer of the funeral of the President it will be a day of sadness
never before witnessed on the Continent - and never
[word lined through]
have any nation in the History of the world been called to mourn for a better man than Abraham Lincoln

div3.head: 19th
div3.p:
The day opened warm and pleasant towards noon became almost hot for the season a better day for the funeral could not have been selected The Sky was a deep blue with scarsely a cloud to mar its beauty at Two oclock all of our Brigade could have ben seen marching for Brigade Headquarters to attend religious
Servise in honor of the day Headquarters are situated in a nice grove in front of the House the walk is bordered by fir trees the shade of which came in good use it being warm enough to ma ke a shade needful for comfort The assembly was addressed by some members of the Christian Commission and Chaplain The day closed as it came in beautiful and pleasant all the day with the exception of servise was used ge as the soldiers seen fit all drilling and unnessary
labor being suspended by order of the War Department.

div3.head: 21st
div3.p:
awoke this morning by noise in camp at Three oclock found we were under marching orders to start at five oclock in about half an hour our bugle sounded and we began to pack up not knowing which way we were to march but the condition of the country up the valley towards Staunton & Lynchough led me to think we would go no further in that direction but I think we will be sent to some Station north of this
where we will stay until we are ordered
[word lined through]
home as I think we will be in course of the summer if we get into no more trouble - We had hardly time to issue rations half of our food was thrown away and all of our beans for three day the men could not carry them they will soon learn to fill their Haversack if they have to take less in their Knapsacks we started on good time the day being cool, and good for marching most of the men are in good marching
order it soon became evident we were taking the road in drection of Harpers Ferry expectful to stop at Summit Station for the night we marched very slow it being only nine miles to the Station we got there about two oclock went to at work and got supper and then put up tents we are camping by the side of the R.R. running from Harpers Ferry to Winchester and near Summit Station we expect a move soon perhaps tomorrow

div3.head: 21st
div3.p:
rainy growing cold fast no drill
ing dress Parade in evening receive daily papers and
[word lined through]
letters also daily the Baltimore American is the principal paper sold.-

div3.head: 22nd
div3.p:
quite pleasant with cold wind had charge of a squad of men for Fatigue duty in fore noon after done all the work sent the men to quarters and took a walk up to the Station there is only two or three houses besides the Depot building all used by the government as are all of the buildings on the R.R. the Road itself belonging
to the Government

div3.head: 23th
div3.p:
Sunday again very cold having thrown away my over coat at Stevenson I suffer some with cold but I have one concilation it will not last long The Spring seems very backward for this latitude but it being between two ranges of mountains I suppose makes some difference There is some nice scenery in this valley at Stevenson we can view Mary land Heights at Harpers Ferry & Manasas
Gap are nearly east The mountains look grand but the country presents a dreary aspect being one [-] camp especially in the vincinty of the R.R. and the whole vally is striped of fences etc.

div3.head: 24th
div3.p:
warmer again drill six hours first thing in morning is roll call each Co - coming out in line of batle with band colan & next comes poliecing quarter then breakfast roll call at half past five. Six oclock is sick call when all
who are wanting medicine must report with a Sergt. at the surgeons tent if able if not the Surgeon visits them in there quarters half past seven the Pickets report at Head Quarters at half past eight guard mounting for camp guard company drill at nine last until Twelve after breakfast those not on other duty get wood if nessary if not spend the time cleaning guns etc washing reading
writing or anything they chose dinner at half past Twelve rest until Two oclock then afternoon drill commences

Company drill for one hour then Batallion drill until five then super and dress Parade at six oclock after dress Parade there is nothing to do till half past eight when we have roll call in company quarters with no accouterments at nine oclock or taps all lights in tents must be blown out rations
are drawn between drill either at morning or evening two or three days rations at a time genarly Tuesday & Thursdays we have Target fireing an hour in fore noon Sundays we have inspection generaly lasting about two hours - the rest of the day we generally have to ourselves when we are not on gurard duty Wednesday in fore noon we have inspection also Saturday afternoon we have for our own
use washing or any thing else we chose

div3.head: 25th
26th
27th
div3.p:
Monthly Inspection today and they boys are very busy until nine oclock cleaning guns Boots etc and came out in nice order but the white gloves are not to be seen but the Colonel gave pretty severe orders that in future on such inspection they must obey all orders from Division Headquarters came off Inspection at noon
not expecting any drill in after noon went off to do roasting but at two oclock we heard the Drums beating but were to far to get there in time So we spent the after noon for our own benefit

div3.head: 28th
div3.p:
Pleasant weather the usual Drill & and the noncommisoned officers went out in the morning for an hour and drilled under the Majors instructions had a good time the Maj said we could Drill with any Comp in the Army The main fault with a new Co is the carelessness of some of
Some others try to do well but a few men can spoil a whole Co

div3.head: 29th
div3.p:
Saturday morning very warm and pleasant on Picket duty for the first time since I am in Va formed infront of Regt. Head quarters at half past Seven OC lock marched to Briga de Headquarters had guard mounting then started to our post in Chare of a Lieut 27 men in a section that divided in to three squads nine men in each I had charge of a station and nine men all I had
to do was to see the men were relieved in time by the Corporal and to see to passes etc had a good time until afternoon when the clouds began to gather and soon it commenced to rain we put up a little shelter with old blankets but it did not keep us very dry it would leak so we sat and took it as cool as possible towards night it came off pleasant again and we had a pretty good night of it just at night a [-] came staggering
up to our lines I examined his pass and pronounced a foragry so I took him to division Headquar ters and had much fun with him but at last I got him safely landed in the guard House at nine oclock next morning we were relieved

sun rose clear and bright at ten oclock we got back to camp and found the Regt out on Inspection after that was through we were mustered for pay I fell into line long enough to answer to my name
we may not get paid for a long time yet but we muster every two months.

div3.head: May 1st
div3.p:
[word lined through]
warm again drilled as usual we get confirmation of the news of Johnsons surrender which we received on Saturday We had not been long on Picket Saturday before we heard a good cheering in Camp one mile from us it soon extended all through the camp and such a cheering we have not heard since we got the news of Lees surrender
The papers say that there is to be a great reduction in the army and its ex pences and that a large portion of it will be sent home before the first of June I think it probale that we will go as we are not attached to any Compy

div3.head: May 2nd
div3.p: Drilled as usual had the best Battalion Drill since we were out the Brigade & Division Comanders were out looking at us we improve fast

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: Arose at five o'clock had roll call h.Co. at nine o'clock fell in for Inspection. There was a man shot close here last night by a safe guard for Straing the halted [-] and he would not stop so he shot and killed him had a good time on afternoon drill

div3.head: 4th
div3.p:
Detailed for Picket Duty The day is warm and pleasant got on my old post had a good time reading & writing letters passed through the lines several Johnies from
Lees army. They were all well. Dressed and in good spirits over the prospects of going home

div3.head: 5th
div3.p: rainy but warm got to camp at ten o'clock found the boys out on drill went out and drilled an hour- in after noon very hot had orders to prepare for grand review to take place on the 7th

div3.head: 6th
div3.p:
rain nearly all fornoon very warm in afternoon Spent the day in clearing of quarters cloths We brought boughs from the woods and put up around Co & Regt
Headquarters and between every tent in the Company we expect to start for Home soon & we are not sorry we are expected to put on considerable style on Review to morrow Boots & strap Blacked white gloves on etc guess we can stand it now the war is over but some of the boys are opposed to it they think the Officers are trying to get us transferred to Hancock Corps to night the Colonel issued a
circular stating it was all a Hoax and that we would soon start for Home I think the boys will go into the Review in better Spirits now that bug bear is out of the way The weather looks very unfavorable for a good day tomorrow now but it may be nice for all that if it is we will have a good time

div3.head: 7th
div3.p:
The day opened cold and cloudy but grew warmer toward noon fell in line at nine oclock had inspection
then Stacked arms. We rested until twelve Ninth started for the place of Review one mile from camp we were Reviewed by Gen{5} & Egan with a numerous Staff There was a splendid Band in attendance who gave us good music The troops behaved well especially in passing the reviewing Officers reched camp at three oclock The troops all wore white gloves after the Review most of the officers and Orderly around Headquarters got on a big drunk

div3.head: 8th
div3.p: drilled etc as usual very warm

div3.head: 9th
div3.p: rainy drill suspeded for good weather

div3.head: 10th
div3.p: on Camp guard rather cool in morning warmer towards night when considerable rain no shelter but as we have expections of leaving the servise soon we had not ought to grumble

div3.head: 11th
div3.p: rainy drill ed in afternoon were driven in in a short time by a heavy storm of wind & rain rained very hard all night

very cold in
morning but grew warmer towards noon drilled a platoon part of the forenoon
[word lined through]
a circular from Gen Egans was read on dress Parade complimenting us for our soldierly appearance on Review last Sunday we expect to leave for Washington soon Policies camp in afternoon preparatory to General Inspection to come of tomorrow got every thing clean and in capital order

div3.head: 14th
div3.p:
Fell in line for Inspection at nine
oclock were Inspected at ten by Inspector Genls of Genl. Egans Staff passed well we had cartridge Straps Blackened & Boots Brasses Bright etc and white gloves so made a very good appearance

div3.head: 15th
div3.p:
Detained for Picket guard Had guard mounting at Regt at half Past Seven o clock marched 1/2 mile to Brgade Headquarters were Inspected and then marched back through camp to Division headquarters one mile from Brgade Head and and then one mile from there to our Picket Post we had
Guard at Division Hdgr it was ten oclock when we got to our Posts I had a squad of nine men we were posted in the edge of a woods it was very cool and shady the
weather
it was very warm in the Sun we are posted on the plantation of a true Union man and they are very scarse
in this valley

div3.head: 16th
div3.p: got back to camp at half past ten lay around at my ease until Dress Parade weather continued warm

div3.head: 17th
div3.p:
Inspection in fore noon in afternoon the weather
being so warm Battalion Drill was postponed and the Officers held a School of the Soldier School after Lessons in Casey we spent the remainder of the afternoon until Dress Parade in playing old [-]
18th

div3.head: 18th
div3.p: warm drilled six hours on comp-y drill the Sergts took command of the Comp-y the Officers being on other Duty

div3.head: 19th
div3.p:
On Picket again went through the same process of Guard mounting
etc rainy most of the day and night were not troubled much by persons passing out and in not being on a road news in camp that we are to start for home soon orders to draw five days rations etc I think we will leave about

div3.head: Sundy 20th
div3.p: Cool but pleasant rained most of the night were not troubled by any one during the night slept from two o'clock until morning

div3.head: May 21st
div3.p: Relieved from picket at ten o clock on getting back to Camp found it had been moved about 1/2 mile into a woods it is a nice cool place went at work putting up tents etc

div3.head: 22nd
div3.p: No drill rainy staid in camp found it not quite as nice as it might be the boys are expecting to go home soon and are getting impatient nothing else talked of

div3.head: 23rd
div3.p: Nothing of importance taking place not as much drill as usual

div3.head: 27th Saturday
div3.p: nice morn and we are still in Old Virgiana the most of us think we shall soon start for home and are not as content as when we expected to stay our year

div3.head: 28th Sunday May
div3.p: On camp guard pleasant until night when it commenced raining but soon cleared up and continued pleasant all night but very dark

div3.head: 29th
div3.p: not very well did not drill any

div3.head: 30th
div3.p:
Still continue
unwell took some medicine felt better toward night no afternoon drill

div3.head: 31st
div3.p: Monthly Insp ection in fore noon no drill in after noon preparing for tomorrow appointed as a fast day by President Johnson

div3.head: June 1st
div3.p: No duty today but necessary guard in afternoon had service at our camp in memory of the Presidents Death very warm

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p:
on Picket guard very warm had a good
time

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: got to camp at ten oclock had no duty to do it being Saturday or wash day

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: Sunday and a Review by Gen Egan Thomas & Mc Cook weather very warm some of the day seven cases of sun stroke before we got back to camp It is not very nice for the men to pack their knapsack a half day in this hot sun for nothing but a useless show and there is much grumbling about it

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
Detailed for four days to guard a RR Bridge at Camp Peck six miles above this place arrived at the Bridge at ten oclock after a warm march found the duty light our force mustered fifty in all only two hours in sixteen for duty the remainder of the time we did about as we are a mind to we expected our provision today but they did not come so we had to forage on the country for our supper we found
plenty of cherries and milk & some of us went fishing some hunting and others swimming the camp is situated on Opequan Creek and found a good place to swim etc 6th Cooler today spent the day in fishing hunting swimming picking cherries etc and a little guard Duty no provisions today heard our Regts 152nd Ind Vol & 194th Ohio had been ordered to Stanton at night we heard that the order was countermanded and we were going to Cumberland Md.
about ten O Clock 192nd Penn came through Camp on their way to Staunton Va

div3.head: 7th
div3.p:
very warm again provisions arrived at noon and found us very hungry for we had nothing only what we picked up in the country
[word lined through]
found that our Regt were still in camp but expecting to go to Cumberland soon although we may be ordered up the Valey any day

div3.head: 8th
div3.p:
warm spent the day as best we could running about the
country making the best of our opportunity as we leave to morrow for our camp at Summit Station

div3.head: 9th
div3.p: relieved by new men at ten o clock about eleven we started for camp the day was warm and we made slow time arrived at camp at three oclock

div3.head: 10th
div3.p: had another Review very warm but we did not remain out as long as usual

div3.head: 11th
div3.p:
the weather being so warm drill has most played out but we still drill from one to two hours
a day playing soldier does not agree with us we do not think they ought to keep us here much longer we enlisted for the war and now the war is over and we are just as anxious to go home as we were willing to come out

div3.head: 12th
div3.p: on camp guard today had a pretty easy time

div3.head: 13th
div3.p:
nothing of inportence taking place in camp some of the officers are sending in their names for the regular
Army and if they pass examination they will get a berth Some of the boys are thinking of enlisting but not as many as there was a short time ago I cannot see any of it for me now they commence recruiting next week

div3.head: 17th
div3.p: on Camp guard again very warm had Inspection in fore noon and did not go on duty until after that relieved at night and went to quarters and sleep

div3.head: 18th
div3.p: My Birthday am twenty one years old I can not see any difference in my actions I have done as I [-] pleased to [--] to see any marked differences after Inspection Walker and myself took a stroll to the picket lines and finding a chance to pass out concluded to improve it and see what we could fine found plenty of cherries Raspber ries etc and some

div3.head: Unknown
div3.p:
had [----] as the men horses had prety hard times hardly any thing to eat toward night lots of us started out in search of shelter some got into the tents with the boy who was stationed here a few got on covered wagons and some went to a covered bridge over Cheat river about two miles
[word lined through]
beyond the the fort I went to the bridge found the water raising very fast large trees were floating down the river one of which struck the bridge and and knocked the bottom plank
out at one end jaming the whole bridge we cut the log in to and let it go down stream the water continued to rise until it got up to the timber of the bridge bridge I thought the bridge would go down soon so I started back toward camp was stoped by the pickets and had to go back; went most to the bridge to where they had some fires built and stoped for the night I pretty near froze had to pull of my socks and wring them every little while had a chill did not care
mutch wether I lived or died took a dose of pain killer whitch helped me some had not a dry stitch on me lots of the men were chilled so the could hardly walk and would have died if it had not been for some who if were stronger helping them up to the fire in

div3.head: 28th
div3.p:
the morning went back to where the regiment was found there had about fifteen horses died in the night and one man drowned between there and our old camp got a cup of warm coffee which helped me some captain
thought I had better come back to our tents so I got into a wagon and started over one of the worst roads that I ever saw I did not get very cold for the jolting of the wagon keep my blood in circulation in Some places their had been a land Slide dow the mountane and filled the road entirely up and in others the wa ter had washed the road away their was about fifty men repairing it we had to go round
by Huttonsville whic h is about sven seaven miles from out tents we got within a mile of there about three oclock P.M. found the bridge gone do overe tygres river gone down stream and the water so high that we could not ford it so I had to wait I went back about a half mile to a deserted house and found some of the boys there and a good fire so I naturly concluded to stop for the night roasted an ear of hard corn eat part of that and a little peice of meat

div3.head: 29th
div3.p: moved today and were glad to get out of the tents

div3.head: 30th
div3.p: drilled twice today in out houses on the manuel of arms

div3.head: December 1st
div3.p: had an inspection of arms knapsacks haversacks & canteens after which there was preaching it don't seem mutch like Sunday the only difference is we don't have to drill

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p: worked on the old gum road chopping logs about 15 miles from hom camp stayed all night in a deserted house had a good fire plenty of fresh pork straw to sleep on

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: got up at daylight cooked our breakfast and chopped until noon got to camp at sun down pretty tired

div3.head: 4th
div3.p:
did nothing
of mutch the most of our the company being on guard

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
had pleasant weather
for several days whitch is something uncommon for Cheat Mountain Summit we were paid of the third and ever since the boys have been speculating quite extensively

div3.head: 6th
div3.p: had a headache and slight toutch of the Agge Staid in quarters most of the day

div3.head: 7th
div3.p: worked in the sawmill quite warm and pleasant

div3.head: 8th
div3.p:
Sunday again and an awful mudy one it is for us it is ankle deep all over Cheat mountain had inspection of knappsacks in morning
slep very warm and comfortable

got up in the morning eat a little more roast corn and started for our wagons found them most ready to cross the river got into a wagon in cross ing the river the water came up to the wagon box I got up to our tents about eleven oclo ck found t a lot of the boys who stayed behind ready to go up the mountain they started in the afternoon I felt pretty weak in hopes of feeling better after I have a little rest

had quite a bad diarhea we here don't know mutch about what is going on in the rest of the world would like very mutch to have some papers to read we have rumors here of a battle at Washington and in Misouria but we don't kow any thing for certain I think we shall have a battle near here soon we have the worst part of the country to work in it is worst both for the horses and men marching over these mountains is no play I think now that we will get out of
here before long but if not we can stand it here as well as anybody there is not over sixty men in our camp now and most of them unwell
unwel but there is no danger of our being attacked here there is lots of Butternuts and chestnuts around here I mean to go out and get some as soon as I get able

div3.head: October 1
div3.p:
felt worse but managed to keep around feel quite lonesome cannot get anything to read or amuse myself with hope soon to be able to go up on the mountain where the boys are two other regiments
went up there today so I guess there is something to be did we have very disagreable weather here it rains about half of the time and the boys who have been here all summer say it is that way all the time I would not pay taxes on
[word lined through]
any land that I have seen in Virgiana yet for it

div3.head: 2th
div3.p:
felt weaker than ever could just get up and down alone I had rather go through most any
[word lined through]
hardships than to be sick in sutch a place as this there is lots of provision
comes in here every day winter will soon set in here in these mountains but I suppose that at least one regiment will winter here
little better just at night receiving a telegraph dispatch that the boys had a fight we get very tired laying around camp

div3.head: 4th
div3.p:
felt quite smart again heard accounts of the fight cant fe believe any thing for certain some accounts say that they are defeated and that the rebels are coming to attack our camp others that our boys whiped them out about two oclock some of our company came in of them we learned
the particulars of the fight our men attacked the rebels in their fortifications the fight lasted about six hours our men behaved like regulars the ninth had the most of the fighting to do they were stationed in front of the enemys batteries in the first of the fight our company lost one man he was killed by a cannon ball our entire loss was twelve or thirteen as near as I can learn the enemy loss we can not acertain but it must have been considerable the boys are
all in good spirits with the exception of a few sick we took thirteen prisoners some horses and a lot of cattle

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
quite smart again captan started
[word lined through]
back to the battle field to recover the body of the man we had killed every man had his own story to tell about the battle we are all getting tired of pork and cracke rs we ought to have some kind of vegrtables at least once a week it would be a great deal better for the mens health I am in
hopes we shall get out of this region soon

went and took a good wash in the river preaching in the fore noon wrote a letter home and received one from home was very glad to get news from home I can tell you we have very bad wether here now rains every day our camp is getting pretty mudy we can live in tents very well in dry wether but it is rather disa greeable in after long rains

div3.head: 7th
div3.p:
rained nearly all day did not have any duty
layed round in camp quite lonesome in after noon some of our company went out on picket guard rather disagreeable work in sutch weather I did not feel well enough to go our officers say now that we will have to winter on top of Cheat Mountain which we don't relish mutch but think we can stand it if any body can

has not stoped raining yet but does not rain as hard as yesterday expect to start for Cheat mountain tomorrow one of our regiment died of typhoid feaver today we buried him
[two words lined through]
according to the honors
of war the band playing a dirge his comrades fired a salute over his grave the second Virginana regiment also buried a man today he was shot acidently or carlisly as I might say another warning against fooling with guns

div3.head: 9th
div3.p:
got up pretty early to get ready for marching
[letter lined through]
boiled a lot of beaf and g to cary along and got breakfast whitch with packing up our knapsacks keep me busy untill half past nine when we took up our line of march we were caried across tygart b river
in wagons we marched six miles over very mudy roads we stoped about 1 oclock rumor says we will go back to Fetterman near Grafton but we cant tell Colonel Milroy is trying every way he can to prevent our having to winter on the mountains but I don't know as he will succeed it has been quite warm here today but grows cold to night it is my impression that we will go to Misouri Kentuckey we are camped a few rods from the place
where we encamped the first night of our expedition against the Secesh the boy on the mountain that is one regiment of them are going to Misouri they passed us today They say the Secesh are leaving there fortifications on Green brier valley it is certain they cannot winter there for they are not used to the cold climate and are poorly clothed now is the time to strike a vigorous blow Secesh can be whiped yet this fall it is my opinion that by spring the confederate army will become
so domoralized as to be of no effect Jeff Davis is beginning to be played out even in the South King Bread will dethrone King Cotton the demand for bred from Europe now
[ word lined through]
exceeds that of cottons come on with your boasted chivalry written by camp fire

div3.head: 11th
div3.p:
resumed our march for Cheat mountain Summit went across a shorter way than to go the road and had some pretty tall climbing whitch before we got up to the road
again verified the old proverb of the longest way round is the shurest way home we got to the Summit it about one oclock we found it looking a little better than when we were here before it being quite warm to what it was when we were here before but it wont last long this is a wild looking place about fourteen miles from where we fough our battle marching over these mountains gives us a good appetite we found our sutler in full blast our boys soon got
[word lined through]
an order from their Captains and he has been
crowded ever since most of the boys spend their wages as
[letter lined through]
though it did not cost them any hard ships we are in camped in a pretty rough place and so steep that I had to stick my heels in the ground to keep from rooling down hill in my sleep and stone enough on the surface to pave the ground and make a fire place and chimney for each tent the boy don't fancy the idea of wintering on these mountains I don't think we will stay there here more than a couple of weeks

div3.head: 11th
div3.p:
[word lined through]
most of the boys bult chimneys to their tents today so they can cook without going out dors - I had some washing to do which keep me busy it is quite warm here today there is a good many of us boys sick there is 1 or to buried here every day out of the Ohio regiments

div3.head: 19th
div3.p:
worked hard all of the fore noon digging out stone on the place ground where we will build our barracks in the afternoon I helped to build a chimney to our tent carrying stone and morter is no
light work and I got prety tired Monday I expect to commence to build our houses the enemy have burnt Green briar bridge so our Scouts say i should not be supprised if we should go out and give them a few shots soon

felt pretty tired laid in tent most of the day wrote some letters we had a very cold night tomorrow we commence cut ting logs for our barracks captain told us to sleep on our arms so if we are attacked we will be ready to give them a warm
reception

did not feel very well worked levaing our ground for the barracks in the fore noon in the afternoon laid around camp and cooked for my mess a great many of our men have the dysentery they get very weak but still are able to get around I have a hard cold and have had since I have been in Va it is a very fogy country some have the rheuymatiz whitch is greatly aggravated by sleeping on the ground one of our company cut of two of his fingers
this fore noon he was getting out timber

div3.head: 15th
div3.p:
this forenoon I had to help build another chimney our messes tent having been left back at Elkwater with two of the mess who were sick in afternoon went and helped cary timber out of the woods whitch is no light work we sent out quite a large scouting party today they drove in the secesh pickets and captured one if they had not been so fast in front they might have captured the whold of their picket part of
our men went around and came up be in the rear of them but they fired to soon in front fe before our men came up in the rear they were most to their camp running like sheep I feel prety tired to night tomorrow I expect we will work on the road

div3.head: 16th
div3.p:
instead of working on the road the captain sent us out scouting the General gave us orders to scout on the mountains that overlook our camp we had a prety rough day of it we went about seven
miles from our camp we did not find any secesh but we found where they had cut pine brush and made a bed we also found tracks in the moss I like scouting first rate but to make interisting I should
[word lined through]
like to scar up a little game once in a while got back to camp at sun down feeling pretty tired

went on picket for the first time I was on the post nearest to the secesh camp with ten others in the afternoon
our scouting party came back reporting a skirmish with the enemys pickets they killed four or five our sutler came back to day with a fresh stock of goods the boys are impatient to get at them he will not sell until tomorrow

div3.head: 20th
div3.p:
got up pretty early and went down to the sutlers and after quite an effort got through the crowd an and bought some crackers and cheese whitch did not go bad had preaching at ten oclock and a temperance lecture in afternoon our chaplin
is rather a mirthful man and got off some pretty good anecdotes at the lecture he does not object to taking a little when he can get a good quality whitch is generally the case but like all good chaplains he abhors tangle foot forty rod etc!

div3.head: 21st
div3.p:
worked today leviling of the ground for the commissary building we get forty cents extra per day for working on our buildings we will have quite a city when we get all of our buildings
up each company is building a house 80 by twenty each company will have its officers quarters besides, the other regiments are also building barracks

div3.head: 29th
div3.p:
not well today started out to work in the morning worked a while and quit it is sutch damp wether here on these mountains heavy fogs most overy every night a
[word lined through]
slave of an arkansas officer came into camp today yesterday he is about half Indian he says they used him pretty hard so he concluded
to leave he seems pretty intelegent he reports mutch sickness in the rebel camp they intend to winter
[word lined through]
some of their troops where they are now

keep our my tent all day had a toutch of the rheumatiz and a very hard cold two of our mess came back from the hospital today their names were H Clanson and J. I Mead they were sick with the typhoid Feaver it is very cold this afternoon commencing to freeze it is getting pretty tough
[word lined through]
for a person to be
sick a person that is well can stand it a little better

div3.head: 24th
div3.p:
felt a little better today the ground froze pretty hard last night we keep up a rousing fire and managed to sleep warm some of our pickets froze to death last night according to report our scouts brought in thirty eight head of cattle 11 horses one rebel and the secesh mail the prisoner was a ragged looking specimen of human nature he is an old scout I supose he has killed
more of our men than any other man in their army here he is abot six feet si four and has a gun about as long
about the same to day did nothing of mutch today

div3.head: 26th
div3.p:
getting a little better
[word lined through]
brought up a little wood we have narrow place to live and do our cooking five men in one of these little tents besides our cooking utensils and having to cook eat sleep wash dishes and do every thing in sutch a small place

Sunday again but it don't seem mutch like Sunday feel a little better better but am very weak just as soon
as I do any hard work I get out of breath and feel weak all over

div3.head: 28th
div3.p:
quite warm again today I fogot to state that the ground froze
[word lined through]
quite hard for two or three nights don't gain strength mutch
had a very pleasant day report came here to day that they are fighting on the Potomac and that General McClellan is driving the rebels out of Mannassas and have captured 38 pieces of Artilary

div3.head: 30th
div3.p:
quite cold again towards evening report our scouts came in and said the rebels were leaving their camp on Greenbriar we immediately sent out 3 or 4 companys to take possession of their
camp and take what prisoners they could

this morning some of the men came back and said that they had been surprised by a superior force and had quite anumber of their men killed after a while we found out the truth of it they built up fires and stood around when they were fired into there was two Ohio boys killed and six wounded they say the Major that had command of the troops was drunk and lead his men into needless danger it was a false report about the rebeels having left their camp and it very careless in the men to build fires

div3.head: Nov 1st
div3.p: work on our houses progresses finely considering the difficulties we have to encounter I am not able to work yet
prety cold here I don't gain strength mutch have a hard cold commenced to storm rain and snows

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: storms awful here to day snows and blows last night we expected half would blow down

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: storm still continues with unabated fury we have our wood to cary about a half mile whitch is not very nice in sutch weather as this

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
the weather is better to day guess we will have
a few days of warmish weather our houses will be done in a week as soon as we get into them our health will be better sleeping on the ground with a few brush under us the ground now being very damp is not very healthy

div3.head: 6th
div3.p: storms worse than ever to day looks dreary round camp

div3.head: 7th
div3.p: weather a little better rains some still I have a very bad toothache face swelled very mutch

the work on our houses
[word lined through]
goes on pretty fast considering the weather whitch still continues bad tooth
[word lined through]
pains me mutch

div3.head: 9th
div3.p:
went and had my face lanced whitch eased it
[word lined through]
I shall be glad
when we get into our houses if we ever do

div3.head: 10th
div3.p: Sunday again but it don't seem mutch like Sunday to us it is pleasant today and the boys are busy at work on the houses it is very mudy here now you one cant go out of a tent with out getting over shoe top in mud

div3.head: 11th
div3.p: rains some today but is quite pleasant to what it is most the time we have a good deal of trouble about our mails we did not receive any mail here from the 3rd until the 10th

div3.head: 12th
div3.p:
pleasant here to day nothing of importance taking place received telegraph dispatch
saying that our fleet had
[word lined through]
landed near Charls ton

sent out a large party scouting about forty went from our company they amounted to 5 or 6 hundred in all to night we heard that our fleet had taken and burnt Charleston 14th our scouts came back this morning they took two prisoners one of them a lieutenant

div3.head: 15th
div3.p: the boys feel pretty sore after their tramp no work done on the houses they say they walked 50 miles
today we have a snow storm very cold the snow is about six inches deep
continues to storm we have it pretty hard getting up wood

div3.head: 18th
div3.p:
am getting quite smart again if I could get rid of my cold
I should consider myself well but it is getting better stood picket today which was not very hard I only had to guard four hours put in a days work on the picket house
got to camp at ten oclock did nothing but cary and chop a little fire wood

div3.head: 20th
div3.p: worked on the house did not thing mutch today rained most all day
worked on the house building chimney

div3.head: 22nd
div3.p: wrote two letters today and carried up all the wood we burned
sick today was taken with the colic and diarrhea feel some better to night

div3.head: 29th
div3.p:
quite smart again it stormed all day so we did not have
any [several words not discernable] yesterday about [words not discernable] went out to the secesh camp they took one cannon they found the secesh all left they [words smudged] [-] five houses
[---] left [several words smudged] to me into there quarters in the fort

div3.head: 26th
div3.p: most of our company moved today
on police guard today [-] our whole mess being on [- -] not move [-] rained all day

built our bunker in [---] and heard a thanksgiving service preasant the fore part of the day rained [--] night
at
[word lined through]
a deserted farm house built up fires and sleep on the ground we are camped in a pictursque place between to mountains we have quite a load to cary two days rations forty round of cartridges knapsack over coat and blanket it is a grand sight to see all of our camp fires and the groups of men around them the men are all contented and ready for any thing that turns up they have confidence in their officers whitch
is half of the battle any time tomorrow we may attact the enemy but we privates don't know mutch about it writen by light of camp fire

waked up laist the night very sick vomited severely sleep little all night felt very weak in the morning got up about four oclock did not feal as though I could go a mile marched about three miles up the mountains sp stoped and rested
[word lined through]
them that wanted to eat their oatcakes and meat I could not eat any we could see from where we was down the valley apiece we stay
evening
went home had a nice ride on the cart found all well and full of pariotism in tended to go out for volunteers but could not get any team
went out after recruits but did not get any for certain attended a meeting of the home guards of Middleburg

div3.head: September 1
div3.p: visited most of the day
started about 11 oclock had a nice ride the camp looked quite [-] again
stood guard fine weather
nothing happens of consequence we [-] our guns
usual drill nothing [---]
received our [-] had a very poor drill [-] in evening
excursion from Elkham drilled in battalion
went out in the morning and practiced pistol shooting spent the rest of the day laying around camp went down town to meeting in evening
received orders to march next day went down town [-] in evening and had a regular spree
expected to march but did not

usual drill went up town and had our coats trimed [-] ex pected hard drill [-]
being to strong for us

marched all night got back to camp about nine oclock eat breakfast went to bed and sleep until after dark the Ohio regiments did not do their duty the ninth and thirtenith Indiana and second Vargiana doing most of the fighting
felt pretty sore our loss is upwards of sixty killed and wounded
the wether continues warm

do not feel very well [-] being three nights without sleep
[-] and sutch a hard march pretty nearly used some of the boys
worked today at the hospital building bunks for the sick 18 feel quite smart again we drilled three times a day now

div3.head: 19th
div3.p: drilled as usual we have pretty comfortable times here now

div3.head: 20th
div3.p: nothing happened today more than usual.

div3.head: 21st
div3.p: the hardest work we have to do is getting our wood we have to cary it quarter of a mile

[-] the usual inspection knappsacks Sunday
is a
[letter lined through]
is a day of rest even in the army we are willing to rest every seven days

div3.head: 23rd
div3.p: on guard and had a pretty cold and stormy time of it it snowed & and blowed as it only can on Cheat Mountain

div3.head: 24th
div3.p: laid around and rested today the storm has abated somewhat Chrismas eve does not seem mutch as it does at home

div3.head: 25th
div3.p: had a Christmas dinner of Buscuit and fried Beaf liver in the after noon had dress parade

div3.head: 26th
div3.p: nothing of consequence happened of importance

div3.head: 27th
div3.p:
nice winter wether again ground froze white
nice getting about here for as soon as it thaws up the mud is knee deep 28th had pretty hard drill

div3.head: 29th
div3.p: spent the day drilling and carrying wood

div3.head: 3th{7}
div3.p: washed today and catched a hard cold

div3.head: 31st
div3.p: had a regimental inspection and were mustered for pay

div3.head: January 1st
div3.p: New years again. had mince pie and chicken for breakfast our company is on guard I stayed and cooked for my mess not being very well to morrow some 500 of our regiment are going out on a scout

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p:
the scouts started about nine
oclock this morning I did not feel well enough to go although I should like to have gone

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: have a very hard head ache and some fever caused by taking cold

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: scouters came back after going out to Green Briar and staying all night they did not drive in the rebel pickets

div3.head: 5th
div3.p: Stormes hard today snows and rains in succession got marching orders for Kentucky expect to start in a few days

div3.head: 6th
div3.p:
snows very hard today we keep pretty close in our quarters tomorrow them that are sick and not very
well will go I expect to go have not been very well for some time

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: very cold and stormy started for Webster about three oclock got to the old hospital at the foot of the mountains a little after dark

div3.head: 8th
div3.p: started pretty early was sick all night with the colic got to Beverly just at dark pretty well tired out took up quarters in the jail commenced raining rained all night

div3.head: 9th
div3.p: rained most all day marched to Bealington had a prety hard time coming over laural mountain

div3.head: 10th
div3.p:
marched to Philippi today over the mudiest roads to be found it was most knee deep
reached Philippi just after dark

div3.head: 11th
div3.p: rained most all day most of our company came in today expect to stay here some days it is rather a dull town but is livelier then it was last fall when we were here
quite warm and pleasant signs of rain

div3.head: 14th
div3.p: left Philippi with about noon for Webster marched eight miles and put up at a farm house had good supper

div3.head: 15th
div3.p:
rained hard all night & fore noon arrived at Webster at noon found it nearly buried in mud Staid
13 the rest of my mess went out in the country today. I was not very well so I remained in town
______________
a couple of hours and got on a train with the sick and came to the hospital at Fetterman being sick with the jaundice

div3.head: 16th
div3.p: quite lonesome in town today the regiment is expected here from Philippi tomorrow

div3.head: 17th
div3.p: the rest of the regiment came in this evening sleep in the tavern in a good bed last night and night before

div3.head: 18th
div3.p:
some of the boys got quite high around
town to day the Colonel ordered no more liquor to be sold to the soldiers posted police guards all over town
on guard to day rains tremendous ordered to go to quarters until called on was not called on at all so I had a pretty comfortable time of it
rains as hard as ever have no fire in our quarters get our cooking done at private dweling the people of this place are quite hospitable

div3.head: 21st
div3.p: the rain has some what abated had dress parade this afternoon the mud was about knee deep

div3.head: 22d
div3.p: on guard to day stood the four hours went to quarters at nine oclock and went to sleep they did not wake me so I escaped four hours guard

div3.head: 23rd
div3.p: scouting party sent out to day about fifty miles on the railroad our company went I not being very well staid behind the{8} took three days rations

div3.head: 24th
div3.p: have a very hard cold being exposed in the rain and having to sleep in cold quarters
have pretty easy times now the company being gone they are expected back some time tonight

div3.head: 26th
div3.p: the boys came back about nine last evening the found no secesh the were all good union men as usual soon as the Yankes as they call them come in sight

div3.head: 27th
div3.p:
sat up all last night at the hospitable and waited on the sick whitch keep me pretty busy had battallion drill and dress parade in the afternoon yester day the [--] Ohio reg came to this place they are well equipid and
armed they think al the citizens here are secesh but they will soon get over that
the weather is very bad the sun has not shone but 45 hours in the last month

div3.head: 29th
div3.p: this place is full of soldiers there is now about 25 hundred here there is a great many of our regt sick with the measles

div3.head: 30th
div3.p:
weather still rainy we have as many men on guard here as we did on Cheat Mountain just as many again as we
have any use for.

div3.head: 31st
div3.p: stood guard today them that have to stand out in the rain have a pretty hard time of it I had a good shelter

div3.head: February 1st
div3.p: yesterday our Captain startted for Indiana recruiting he will be absent two months he is liked by all of his men.

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p:
today the 73d Ohio left here I suppose they go to Romney they are a noble looking set of men that is the most of them there is a great many of old men in
the regiment

div3.head: 3rd
div3.p: we have quit drilling the officers found that it was a shure way to kill off the men to get them out and drill them in the mud and rain

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: on guard again to day for being absent from roll call since the Captain has been absent they have roll call very irregular and as I am not staying where the rest of the company do I am some times absent

div3.head: 5th
div3.p:
to day has been very warm and pleasant it is the first day the sun has
shone all day in the last 20 days four companyes of our regiment are
[word lined through]
have gone to Rose burg to gurard a bridge it is about twenty five miles from Grafton and our company have gone to Grafton to guard

div3.head: 6th
div3.p:
today it rains again the men are dieing very fast at the hospital there has over twenty died since we have been in this place our Colonel has got the mumps I have been exposed to them but I don't think
I shall have thim

div3.head: 7th
div3.p: the weather is still stormy the natives they have never saw sutch weather as we have had for the last four months went up [an indiscernible word] Grafton on the cass today it is not mutch of a place what we would call a one horse town in Indiana

div3.head: 8th
div3.p: we received marching orders for Kentucky today I understand General Milroy is to go with us our company have lost 4 men since we have been in this place

div3.head: 9th
div3.p:
on guard to day but being of most
{9}all day

div3.head: 10th
div3.p:
lounged about town all day expect the paymaster in a few days the boys mony is all played out and they have to go it on trust, and if we are not paid before we leave Fetterman I am afraid it will be a great while before some while of them get their pay last night some of our boys broke into a grocery & caried of a keg of Brandy besides several
{10}are going it high

div3.head: 11th
div3.p: last night our hospital caught fire and burned to the ground the sick were all carried out uninjured this morning I went out about a mile in the country and bought a chicken and had a glorious old dinner I don't think we will leave this place before the first of next week

div3.head: 12th
div3.p:
the snow was two
inches deep this morning but before night was all gone I am getting some what tired of this place it is the same thing over every day we need some excitement to keep us in good spirits

div3.head: 13th
div3.p:
had battalion drill this morning and company drill in the afternoon our company turned out twenty five privates whitch was doing better than some of the companyies this afternoon one of our
[word lined through]
mess was
taken down with the measles

div3.head: 14th
div3.p: rains and snows quite hard today the cheering news whitch we are hering from the army on the Mississippi and on the Atlantic coast raises the boys spirits a great deal it look some now like making a short war of it

div3.head: 15th
div3.p:
snows quite fast today and if it keeps on the people of Feltesman will yet have a chance for a sleigh ride towards night the wether got
very cold and made us think of Cheat Mountain

div3.head: 16th
div3.p: Sunday here again rooled around but to us it seems about the same as any other day this evening we received the glorious news that fort Donaldson is ours and fifteen thousand prisoners & four generals with their arms and stores and sutch a yelling among the boys Fettermen will not often see

div3.head: 17th
div3.p:
the news of our victory was
confirmed today it has rained most all day and their being a couple inches of snow it is very disagreeable getting about

div3.head: 18th
div3.p: sick with the mumps quite warm & pleasant the papers today brought the account of the fight at Fort Donaldson old Floyd it appears has escaped the regiment was out this afternoon and had a skirmish drill & fired a few rounds of Blank cartridges

div3.head: 19th
div3.p: received marching orders ealy this morning busy all day packing up marched to the train at four oclock got almost ready to start when we were ordered to our quarters until four oclock next morning

div3.head: 20th
div3.p: got aboard the cars at four this morning & run down some twenty miles on the Parkersburg road where we found the road obstructed by a land slide here we had to stay until twelve oclock at night the weather is very cold but we have a pretty tight car so we managed to keep warm ________

div3.head: 21st
div3.p: arrived at Parkersburg about three oclock there is apwards of th twenty tunnels between Grafton & Parkersburg here we crossed the Ohio & took cars on the Marietta & Cincinati Road for we did not start until quite late at night the boys all feel glad to get out of Virgnana Parkersburg is quite an important place

div3.head: 22nd
div3.p:
the cars having a good many heavy grades to go up and being loaded pretty heavy run slow
& it was almost dark before we got to Chilacoth here we stoped some the people seemed glad to see us we got to Cincinati about two oclock being pretty tired of railroading on the Cincinati road we had passinger cars to ride in we found them a little more comfortable than the freight cars whitch we had to ride in in Va

div3.head: 23rd
div3.p:
went aboard steamboat in the three oclock in night started abu at daylight had a very pleasant ride
down the river the shores of the Ohio are crowded with towns & we were greeted with waving of hankerchiefs & hurrahs from all of them our regiment occupies two boats whitch are fastened together we arrived at Lousiville at dark the weather not being very cold I went up on the upper deck to sleep about midnight there came up a gale of wind whitch blew so hard I was obliged to go blow

div3.head: 24th
div3.p:
we we occupied most of the day loading on stores of various kinds also a lot of mules and wagons went ashore in the afternoon and took a look at the town it is quite a pleasant place General Ruels body guard left here this afternoon on the Steamer Prioress they are noble looking men & look as if they might do some fighting there was some of the fort Donaldson prisoners in town today but I did not see them it is the impression of the now that we will go to Fort Donaldson
some of the Boys found a little to mutch liquor ashore today and came aboard in a ratther worse for wear we started down the River again at dark

div3.head: 25th
div3.p: not very well to day had quite a hard feaver last night nothing happened of importance today passed several nice looking towns at one of them where we stoped to take in coal several of our boys went ashore to get there Bitters and were left behind

div3.head: 26th
div3.p:
quite warm to about nine oclock we entered the mouth
of the Cumberland whitch is quite a large stream the weather here seems like May in Indiana we expect to arrive at Fort Dolalson tomorrow the people along the shore speak to be mostly Union but it is likely the last events of the last two weeks has had some effect on them the river is very high the land is flooded for miles around we passed a sunken steamboat today it stuck on a
[word lined through]
snag

we make very slow time not more than three miles an hour there
has fifteen or twenty thousand troops gone up this river since the Fort Donaldson Fight and more comming stoped & took on a lot of secesh wood the owner came aboard & said he was a secesh and as he did not like to take the oath of alegrance got no pay for his wood about nine oclock at night we passed Fort Donaldson the camp fires extended of for miles we was all anxious to go & and see the Battle Field
but were obliged to pass on .

div3.head: 28th
div3.p: rainy & cold go very slow not over two miles an hour reached Clarksville at dark it is quite a large town the rebels built some Fortifications here but left them without firing a gun we laid up here all night & took in Commisary stores the secesh left lots of provisions here the people are the rankest kind of secesh a few companies of Iillinois & Kentucky troops hold the town

div3.head: Febru March 1st
div3.p:
started at daylight passed several steamers going down the river with troops I should think if they expected a fight near Nashville they would keep all of the troops there the news at Clarksville is that the rebels have fell back thirty miles from Nashville there is many high bluffs along the river and the buzzards live around them in great quantities the appears to be faceing some now tied up at
dark having made about twenty five miles

div3.head: 2nd
div3.p:
the sun arose very warm and pleasant but it soon clouded up and by noon it rained quite smart - had preaching on deck in forenoon we saw several large groups of darkies who came down to the bank to gaze at us. a steamer passed us about noon some are
[word lined through]
on board suny out all night at Nashville towards night it rained tremendous

div3.head: 3d
div3.p:
arrived at Nashville about ten oclock last night found that the
secesh had left the city and vicinity our company is on guard today we left the boat about two oclock marched through town & out into the country a couple of miles to our camp ground saw
[word lined through]
several old friends of the twenty ninth regiment

div3.head: 4th
div3.p: staid in camp and cleaned up did not drill any have stoves in our tents they are sibley tents we have seventeen in our tent

div3.head: 5th
div3.p: drilled nearly all day in towards night went out to see a man shot they was eight or ten regiments out to see it he blonged to the twenty fourth Ohio regt his crime was trying to shoot the corporal of the guard the weather is very cold

div3.head: 6th
div3.p:
on guard it snowed nearly all day and cold enough to freese we have to sleep prety close I have not been out of Camp but once only five are
allowed out of the regiment at a time

div3.head: 7th
div3.p: our company is on picket I came off guard at nine oclock went out on skirmish drill in the afternoon I put in the rest of the day writing and washing

div3.head: 8th
div3.p:
on guard again today the weather is warm and mild our regiment had a guard inspection by the Colon el Commanding the brig [-] orders are very strict here some of our
[word lined through]
officers are under arrest

div3.head: 9th
div3.p: had company inspection of Knapsacks [-] etc at nine oclock quite warm and pleasant spent the rest of the day writing [--] at sundown a skirmish is reported to have taken place this morning Nine miles from here

div3.head: 10th
div3.p: unwell today very bad diarrhea rained nearly all day no drill dress parade at sundown

div3.head: 11th
div3.p:
sill quite unwell the medicine the doctor gave me consisted of four monstrous large quinine powders whitch
is rather poor medicine for soldiers who have to sleep on the damp ground & are exposed to nearly every rain storm tomorrow our regiment is going out on a scout they make the sick men stand guard so that all the able men can go I had to stand allnight although I felt hardly able to stand up

today the regiment march out to where Generall Jackson is buried I should have liked to have been along but was not able it is twelve miles from
should but I got my knappsack hauld

div3.head: 20th
div3.p:
rained this morning we did not march
[word lined through]
we all feel pretty sore

div3.head: 21st
div3.p: marched three miles and encamped I am on guard we may stay here some time it is reported in camp that General Nelson is under arrest for marching so near to NC Cooks division and having the pickets fighting he is disliked by nearly all the division

div3.head: 22nd
div3.p:
I did not drill not being very well the
weather is very cold

div3.head: 23d
div3.p: had inspection today the rest of the time laid around camp 2 snowed some very cold for Dixie

div3.head: 24th
div3.p: our lieutenant commanding company was arrested for because the General found a few pieces of rail [?] by our fires and two of our cooks tied up to a tree he was released before night the General is a perfect old tyrant

div3.head: 25th
div3.p: weather quite warm again

div3.head: 26st
div3.p:
this afternoon we cleared
up a field of Cotton stalks and
[word lined through]
burned them so as to have the field for a drill ground

div3.head: 27th
div3.p: Co C is on picket the weather is warm and we had a good time standing picket in warm weather is pretty easy work

div3.head: 28th
div3.p: came of picket at ten oclock had battallion drill in afternoon tomorrow we march for Columbia eight miles from here

div3.head: 29th
div3.p:
started at seven oclock had to ford Duck river the watter
is three feet deep
{11} Notes on Paridise Lost the poet first speaks of mans disobediance & fall & then of the revolt in heaven & its consequences & of the Rebel angels being cast into Perditio and of their being confounded & confused described their abode the Rings of fallen angles
[word lined through]
addressing his compeer in power known as Satan in bold words Satan answers with word of desperate courage
the arch Fiend replied and counseled for resistance the arch Fiend is represented as laying on a lake of fire

del.hi: Lieut Col Sanford Stoughton of the 44th Md formerly of Leig- omer has been appon inted Col of the 100th
